articles.headline: 9/11 Polls Find Lingering Fears in New York
articles.snippet: Outside of New York, however, Americans seem to have adjusted to a “new normal,” two Times/CBS News polls suggest.
articles.abstract: Outside of New York, however, Americans seem to have adjusted to a “new normal,” two Times/CBS News polls suggest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years after the Sept. 11 attacks, two-thirds of New Yorkers say they are still “very concerned” about another attack on their city, a level of apprehension only slightly reduced from the fall of 2001, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News polls of the nation and New York City.
articles.byline: By Robin Toner and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: Merck Inquiry Backs Conduct Over Vioxx
articles.snippet: An investigator hired by the company’s board found that Merck took “reasonable steps” to research Vioxx’s health risks.
articles.abstract: An investigator hired by the company’s board found that Merck took “reasonable steps” to research Vioxx’s health risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 20 months and $21 million, the investigator that Merck’s board hired to examine the company’s conduct regarding Vioxx has rendered his verdict: The company behaved more or less perfectly.

articles.headline: In a Sea of Cellphones, a Pearl
articles.snippet: The BlackBerry Pearl is a do-everything device that comes closer to the perfect cellphone than anything before it.
articles.abstract: The BlackBerry Pearl is a do-everything device that comes closer to the perfect cellphone than anything before it.

articles.headline: Taking the Wheel
articles.snippet: After 37 years at Boeing, Ford’s new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, must quickly get up to speed during one of the company’s most severe financial crises.
articles.abstract: After 37 years at Boeing, Ford’s new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, must quickly get up to speed during one of the company’s most severe financial crises.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 6 — The day after he was named the Ford Motor Company’s new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally walked onto a stage with his boss, William Clay Ford Jr., before hundreds of applauding Ford employees, with thousands more watching via the company’s Web site and closed-circuit television.

articles.headline: Labor Costs Shake a Pillar of Fed Policy
articles.snippet: A new report suggested that the threat of higher inflation had not diminished and that it may take more monetary restraint to hold prices down.
articles.abstract: A new report suggested that the threat of higher inflation had not diminished and that it may take more monetary restraint to hold prices down.
articles.lead_paragraph: As inflation edged higher this year, many economists — including those at the Federal Reserve — pointed to higher productivity and stable labor costs as signs that prices were not likely to rise unchecked.

articles.headline: Israel Will Ease Grip on Lebanon
articles.snippet: Israel said it would end its blockade of Lebanon after being assured that international forces would stop arms from being smuggled to Hezbollah.
articles.abstract: Israel said it would end its blockade of Lebanon after being assured that international forces would stop arms from being smuggled to Hezbollah.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, Sept. 6 — Israel announced Wednesday that it would lift its air and sea blockade of Lebanon on Thursday evening, three weeks after the cessation of hostilities, because international forces were ready to move into place to impose an arms embargo on the Hezbollah militia.

articles.headline: A Board in Need of an Emily Post
articles.snippet: The boardroom clashes at Hewlett-Packard have advisers talking: Should what happens in the boardroom stay in the boardroom?
articles.abstract: The boardroom clashes at Hewlett-Packard have advisers talking: Should what happens in the boardroom stay in the boardroom?
articles.lead_paragraph: Boardrooms have erupted in battles in the past, but the clashes at Hewlett-Packard over leaks and questionably obtained phone records have lawyers and corporate-governance experts aghast at the strange drama unfolding.

articles.headline: Leak, Inquiry and Resignation Rock a Boardroom
articles.snippet: A battle on Hewlett-Packard’s board is the latest episode in a soap opera that began with the C.E.O.’s ouster in 2005.
articles.abstract: A battle on Hewlett-Packard’s board is the latest episode in a soap opera that began with the C.E.O.’s ouster in 2005.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6  As corporate intrigue goes, it is hard to beat this: an uproar over news leaks from the boardroom, a cloak-and-dagger investigation, allegations of spying and double-dealing, and a clash involving some of Silicon Valley’s best-known names that could end in lawsuits and possibly criminal charges.

articles.headline: President Moves 14 Held in Secret to Guantanamo
articles.snippet: The announcement was the first time President Bush had acknowledged the existence of secret C.I.A. prisons abroad.
articles.abstract: The announcement was the first time President Bush had acknowledged the existence of secret C.I.A. prisons abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 — President Bush said Wednesday that 14 high-profile terror suspects held secretly until now by the Central Intelligence Agency — including the man accused of masterminding the Sept. 11 attacks — had been transferred to the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to face military tribunals if Congress approves.

articles.headline: Taking the Wheel
articles.snippet: The day after he was named the Ford Motor Company's new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally walked onto a stage with his boss, William Clay Ford Jr., before hundreds of applauding Ford employees, with thousands more watching via the company's Web sit...
articles.abstract: The day after he was named the Ford Motor Company's new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally walked onto a stage with his boss, William Clay Ford Jr., before hundreds of applauding Ford employees, with thousands more watching via the company's Web site and closed-circuit television.     Once the clapping died down, the questions, many of them pointed, began. Even though Mr. Mulally will not start until Oct. 1, the interrogation suggested that his honeymoon with employees at the struggling automaker could be short.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 6 - The day after he was named the Ford Motor Company's new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally walked onto a stage with his boss, William Clay Ford Jr., before hundreds of applauding Ford employees, with thousands more watching via the company's Web site and closed-circuit television.

articles.headline: President Moves 14 Held in Secret to Guantanamo
articles.snippet: President Bush said Wednesday that 14 high-profile terror suspects held secretly until now by the Central Intelligence Agency -- including the man accused of masterminding the Sept. 11 attacks -- had been transferred to the detention center at Gua...
articles.abstract: President Bush said Wednesday that 14 high-profile terror suspects held secretly until now by the Central Intelligence Agency -- including the man accused of masterminding the Sept. 11 attacks -- had been transferred to the detention center at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to face military tribunals if Congress approves.     The suspects include Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, thought to be the Sept. 11 mastermind, and other close associates of Osama bin Laden. Mr. Bush said he had decided to ''bring them into the open'' after years in which the C.I.A. held them without charges in undisclosed sites abroad, in a program the White House had not previously acknowledged.

articles.headline: Leak, Inquiry and Resignation Rock a Boardroom
articles.snippet: As corporate intrigue goes, it is hard to beat this: an uproar over news leaks from the boardroom, a cloak-and-dagger investigation, allegations of spying and double-dealing, and a clash involving some of Silicon Valley's best-known names that cou...
articles.abstract: As corporate intrigue goes, it is hard to beat this: an uproar over news leaks from the boardroom, a cloak-and-dagger investigation, allegations of spying and double-dealing, and a clash involving some of Silicon Valley's best-known names that could end in lawsuits and possibly criminal charges.      The furor at Hewlett-Packard, the giant personal computer and printer company, began unfolding when Thomas J. Perkins, a pioneer venture capitalist, quit the board after an investigation pointed to a friend on the board as a source of the news leaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6 - As corporate intrigue goes, it is hard to beat this: an uproar over news leaks from the boardroom, a cloak-and-dagger investigation, allegations of spying and double-dealing, and a clash involving some of Silicon Valley's best-known names that could end in lawsuits and possibly criminal charges.

articles.headline: Merck Inquiry Backs Conduct Over Vioxx
articles.snippet: After 20 months and $21 million, the investigator that Merck's board hired to examine the company's conduct regarding Vioxx has rendered his verdict: The company behaved more or less perfectly.     So said a former federal judge, John S. Martin Jr...
articles.abstract: After 20 months and $21 million, the investigator that Merck's board hired to examine the company's conduct regarding Vioxx has rendered his verdict: The company behaved more or less perfectly.     So said a former federal judge, John S. Martin Jr., after an inquiry into whether the senior management at Merck hid the risks of Vioxx, its former best-selling pain drug.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 20 months and $21 million, the investigator that Merck's board hired to examine the company's conduct regarding Vioxx has rendered his verdict: The company behaved more or less perfectly.

articles.headline: Labor Costs Shake a Pillar of Fed Policy
articles.snippet: As inflation edged higher this year, many economists -- including those at the Federal Reserve -- pointed to higher productivity and stable labor costs as signs that prices were not likely to rise unchecked.      But a new Labor Department report ...
articles.abstract: As inflation edged higher this year, many economists -- including those at the Federal Reserve -- pointed to higher productivity and stable labor costs as signs that prices were not likely to rise unchecked.      But a new Labor Department report suggested yesterday that the threat of higher inflation had not diminished and that it might take more monetary restraint to hold prices down. The report found unit labor costs -- which take into account changes in productivity and hourly wages -- increased much more sharply in the first half of the year than the government first calculated.
articles.lead_paragraph: As inflation edged higher this year, many economists -- including those at the Federal Reserve -- pointed to higher productivity and stable labor costs as signs that prices were not likely to rise unchecked.

articles.headline: A Board in Need of an Emily Post
articles.snippet: Boardrooms have erupted in battles in the past, but the clashes at Hewlett-Packard over leaks and questionably obtained phone records have lawyers and corporate-governance experts aghast at the strange drama unfolding.      ''This is a very, very ...
articles.abstract: Boardrooms have erupted in battles in the past, but the clashes at Hewlett-Packard over leaks and questionably obtained phone records have lawyers and corporate-governance experts aghast at the strange drama unfolding.      ''This is a very, very messy situation for Hewlett-Packard,'' said Nell Minow, co-founder of the Corporate Library, a corporate governance research firm. ''This is a board that grossly overpaid the departing C.E.O. and handled the unpleasantness with the Compaq merger very badly. People just don't have a lot of patience with this board anymore.''
articles.lead_paragraph: Boardrooms have erupted in battles in the past, but the clashes at Hewlett-Packard over leaks and questionably obtained phone records have lawyers and corporate-governance experts aghast at the strange drama unfolding.

articles.headline: In a Sea of Cellphones, a Pearl
articles.snippet: EVERYONE knows that the perfect cellphone doesn't exist, and it's mostly because of physics. You know: You can't have a huge screen on a tiny phone, or a fat battery on a slim phone, or top-of-the-line construction at a rock-bottom price.      But...
articles.abstract: EVERYONE knows that the perfect cellphone doesn't exist, and it's mostly because of physics. You know: You can't have a huge screen on a tiny phone, or a fat battery on a slim phone, or top-of-the-line construction at a rock-bottom price.      But design constraints are part of the problem, too. Packing hundreds of features into a tiny device, in a simple, efficient way, seems to be harder to do than cracking the human genome.

articles.headline: 9/11 POLLS FIND LINGERING FEARS IN NEW YORK CITY
articles.snippet: Five years after the Sept. 11 attacks, two-thirds of New Yorkers say they are still ''very concerned'' about another attack on their city, a level of apprehension only slightly reduced from the fall of 2001, according to the latest New York Times/...
articles.abstract: Five years after the Sept. 11 attacks, two-thirds of New Yorkers say they are still ''very concerned'' about another attack on their city, a level of apprehension only slightly reduced from the fall of 2001, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News polls of the nation and New York City.     Nearly a third of New Yorkers said they thought about Sept. 11 every day. Nearly a third said that they had not gone back to pre-Sept. 11 routines and that they were still dealing with changes caused by the attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five years after the Sept. 11 attacks, two-thirds of New Yorkers say they are still "very concerned" about another attack on their city, a level of apprehension only slightly reduced from the fall of 2001, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News polls of the nation and New York City.
articles.byline: By Robin Toner and Marjorie Connelly

articles.headline: A Challenge From Bush to Congress
articles.snippet: In calling for public war-crime trials at Guantánamo Bay, President Bush is calculating that with a critical election just nine weeks away, neither angry Democrats nor nervous Republicans will dare deny him the power to detain, interrogate and try...
articles.abstract: In calling for public war-crime trials at Guantánamo Bay, President Bush is calculating that with a critical election just nine weeks away, neither angry Democrats nor nervous Republicans will dare deny him the power to detain, interrogate and try suspects his way.     For years now, Guantánamo has been a political liability, regarded primarily as a way station for outcasts. By transforming Guantánamo instead into the new home of 14 Qaeda leaders who rank among the most notorious terror suspects, Mr. Bush is challenging Congress to restore to him the authority to put the United States' worst enemies on trial on terms he has defined.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6 - In calling for public war-crime trials at Guantánamo Bay, President Bush is calculating that with a critical election just nine weeks away, neither angry Democrats nor nervous Republicans will dare deny him the power to detain, interrogate and try suspects his way.

articles.headline: Israel Will Ease Grip on Lebanon
articles.snippet: Israel announced Wednesday that it would lift its air and sea blockade of Lebanon on Thursday evening, three weeks after the cessation of hostilities, because international forces were ready to move into place to impose an arms embargo on the Hezb...
articles.abstract: Israel announced Wednesday that it would lift its air and sea blockade of Lebanon on Thursday evening, three weeks after the cessation of hostilities, because international forces were ready to move into place to impose an arms embargo on the Hezbollah militia.     Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said Israel would yield its ''control positions over Lebanon's seaports and airports'' at 6 p.m. Thursday to international supervision.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, Sept. 6 - Israel announced Wednesday that it would lift its air and sea blockade of Lebanon on Thursday evening, three weeks after the cessation of hostilities, because international forces were ready to move into place to impose an arms embargo on the Hezbollah militia.
